Change has been successfully rebased and submitted as 387a6191f225335caa052522b4774cdb70853189

Just wanted to add more context, all the interface and properties added here are based on Redfish Spec https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP2046_2022.3.pdf page 216, ComponentIntegrity schema. 

Redfish defined the ComponentIntegrity schema, the properties.

I'm trying to translate the Redfish spec to DBus spec, so that when dbus daemon collecting properties for redfish request, it will be consistent and no extra work is needed to convert the data.

> I'm trying to translate the Redfish spec to DBus spec, so that when dbus daemon collecting properties for redfish request, it will be consistent and no extra work is needed to convert the data.

This isn't what we do though.  If we did that, the BMC codebase would just become a big Redfish engine.  AMI tried that with IPMI and their codebase was stuck as a big out-of-date IPMI engine.  We're not going to make that same mistake with s/IPMI/Redfish/.
Thanks a lot for your detailed review, very helpful! I will work on a updated version soon.

Definitely don't want this to be at the top-level.

Is this considered "Inventory"?  Maybe "State"?
The updated version put ComponentIntegrity under Inventory/Decorator, as explained in the updated commit msg.
Do any of these properties need a "readonly" flag?  I suspect most of them you are _not_ expecting other daemons to modify.

Yes, a few of them are read/write, many are read-only. Thanks for the reminder! I will update it:
- read/write: Enabled
- read-only:Type, TypeVersion, LastUpdated,ComponentsProtected, TargetComponentURI
Done

What ends up being the utility of this?  We generally don't like raw strings that might end up being interpreted by other code.  Maybe this is just for humans.

You might want to document the format here.  Are you expecting something like "1.3" for a TPM?
It is for humans, just like the example you give: "1.3" for a TPM, or "1.1" for a SPDM-capable device. So should be ok to use string type.
Done

What does "updated" mean in this context?  Some kind of firmware update applied or a state change?  This is ambiguous enough that we at least need more words in the description and potentially a different property name.
Good point! This could be any component integrity information change, including a firmware update, certificate change, security protocol version update. I will add more description.
Done
Please look at Associations.  You shouldn't directly hold a object_path like this to a static peer object.
I took a look at association. I agree it is a better option. Let me test the association based implementation.
Done
This probably belongs in an association as well.
Ack. The same as the above. Let me test the association.
Done

Do you need an "Unknown"?

The result of putting OEM first is that that ends up being the default value for the property (Type).  I'm not sure if that's what you desire.
This looks good to me. SPDM and TPM are the well known one. If we don't know, it could be OEM-specific (similar to unknown), which sounds like a safe assumption to me.
Done

What ends up being the utility of this?  We are generally trying to avoid protocol-specifics bleeding out into other applications so when I see an interface named the same as a protocol it stands out.
Removed it in the latest patch.
Looks like this is an association.
Ack

Lots of SPDM-specific stuff is showing up on dbus.  I haven't reviewed this  interface because it just looks like associations.

Need to see a design doc to understand what you're trying to accomplish by exposing SPDM directly onto dbus.

So the idea is to allow a remote attester to do SPDM-based authentication to a device. It is a very useful feature in data center where remote attestation is needed everywhere to authenticate the device's firmware integrity or hardware identity. Typically, the BMC will get the attestation request(typically over a redfish request) and then the device dbus agent can handle the attestation request. That's why we have the properties defined here. We have the requester info, responder, responder's authentication(which is a certificate object).

SPDMGetMeasurements is a SPDM-specific interface to get measurements (firmware or hardware config) of devices.

 Hope this help answer your question.
Done
size, not uint32.
got it, thanks
Done
size, not uint32.
Ack

Hi Patrick, I've uploaded a newer version of patchset, where I addressed all your comments. Could you please take a look? I've verified it by testing on a dbus daemon using the dbus interfaces defined here, especially the associations.
@patrick@stwcx.xyz Hi Patrick, could you help review this updated version? Thanks!
Could you help take a look and give feedback on the new proposal of where should all integrity measurement interfaces go? Thanks!
Proposing creating a directory Attestation in DBus and put all integrity/identity/measurement related interfaces under it. See details in newly added comment.

You've called this an Inventory.Decorator, but it isn't obvious to me which inventory object(s) you expect this to be a decorator for.  You've listed associations, but it kind of seems like his would be on one of the two items you've listed potential associations to?

Initially,I thought "Integrity" info seems to be a decorator of an Item. However, it is not like the other decorator info that are static info collected from hardware items.

I did a exhaustive search under /xyz/openbmc_project/ and found no good place for these integrity attestation related interfaces. For example:

top candidates considered:
State : it's for power state management of BMC, HOST, CHASSIS for phosphor-state-manager
Inventory: it is for static inventory information of items

dbus management:
Association 
Object
Time
User
Common
Collection


subsystem management:
Memory
Network 
Memory
Led
Chassis 
Channel
BIOSConfig
Sensor
Smbios
Certs
Software
HardwareIsolation: information of isolated hardware

specific protocol:
PLDM
MCTP
Ipmi 

Other:
PFR: platform firmware resiliency
Condition: Host firmware condition
Telemetry
Dump


Given Integrity measurement is a piece of important security information that is orthogonal to other categories defined under /xyz/openbmc_project/. Would it make sense to create a "Integrity" directory under /xyz/openbmc_project/ to provide integrity measurement related interfaces and put ComponentIntegrity, IdentityAuthentication, MeasurementSet interface under it. We will have something like below:

yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Integrity/ComponentIntegrity.interface.yaml
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Integrity/IdentityAuthentication.interface.yaml
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Integrity/MeasurementSet.interface.yaml

What do you think?

I am thinking about a better name to group these integrity/identity/measurement related interfaces, like Attestation. We can put those interfaces related to attestation management here. For example, attest the component integrity, component identity, or firmware/hardware configuration from secure measurement. 

yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Attestation/ComponentIntegrity.interface.yaml
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Attestation/IdentityAuthentication.interface.yaml
yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/Attestation/MeasurementSet.interface.yaml

In the future, if we have other security protocols that does attestation and need to expose attestation status/results over dbus, they can use existing interfaces or add new interfaces under Attestation/.

I suspect this should be readonly also?  Do you really want another daemon to be able to write this property?

There might be some confusion between:
  * normal
  * readonly
  * const
  
const won't send signals because the implementation is not allowed to change the value once the object is constructed.  readonly means that a dbus-client cannot write to the value.
Make sense, Will do. No client should be allowed to update it.
Please also add these to the other end for documentation.
Will do
This isn't an Inventory.Decorator.  Inventory shouldn't have state changes like this.  It isn't obvious to me where you expect this to live in dbus.
Ack

Do you want 18 and 27 to be the same?

Please document the reverse link in the Certs.Certificate.
Ack

Do you need 'Unknown'?

The default for ResponderVerificationStatus is going to end up being Failed, unless you set a default on line 8.

Make sense, let me add an unknown status here, which will give more info about the attestation status in D-Bus.

To be noted, this is security authentication, an "Unknown" status is almost equal to "FAILED" to the authenticator as the authenticator can not trust it. The Redfish spec only have Success and Failed defined, so both the "Unknow" and "Failed" will be merged and reported as "Failed" to the authenticator.
I don't think this belongs in Inventory.  Inventory should be for static data.
Ack
Hi Patrick, could you help take a look at this updated version? Thanks!
Hi Patric, could you help review this updated version? Thank you!
Adding Nan Zhou, Nancy Yuen and William Kennington to help with the review, thanks!

@patrick@stwcx.xyz, Hi Patrick, thanks a lot for your constructive feedback! I have fixed the comments accordingly. Now I also get it reviewed with Nan who has rich experience in openbmc and get a +1. Could you help review it again and +2 it if it looks good to you? Thanks!

Not typically how I see dates here. 
Does uint64 work?

https://github.com/openbmc/phosphor-dbus-interfaces/blob/4f6fbeab36c23cce3816f0f6de4c92b9b87774b7/yaml/xyz/openbmc_project/State/BMC.interface.yaml#L19
Prefer string here: this LastUpdated date here is for human readers. If we store it as string here, it will avoid transforming it again from uint64 to string.
bmcweb could convert the timestamp to human readable strings, but on dbus, uint64 epoch timestamp looks more suitable here, which is also consistent with other interfaces (e.g. dump entry)
If uint64 epoch for timestamp is the d-bus convention, I'm happy to follow it.
Ack
Should this be `array[byte]`?

`size` here represents the "size" of the measurementindices array. `byte` will put a limit on the number of possible measurement blocks(limit to 256). Even though the current SPDM spec does have a limit of 256 max blocks, I'm not sure if we want to have a hard limit here given the spec may change to accept more blocks.

The `size` here is the data type in the array, not the size of the array.
With `size`, it effectively becomes std::vector<size_t> in C++, but I think it makes more sense for `std::vector<uint8_t>` for this property.

As explained in the previous comment, the idea of using `size` type (`size_t` effectively in C++, which is also compatible with redfish spec) is that we don't want to put a hard tight limit on the array size, thus making this interface more stable. For example, if we use byte here, it will be tightly binded to the current SPDM spec. If anything changed in the SPDM spec, there will be a chain reaction to the bmcweb, dbus interface.

>  we don't want to put a hard tight limit on the array size, thus making this interface more stable.

As indicated in above comment, the size here is not for the array size, but the type of the object in the array.
I mean if the data type is uint8_t or byte, then the biggest array size is (2**8-1) which is 255. If it is size_t, we don't have such a limit.

> I mean if the data type is uint8_t or byte, then the biggest array size is (2**8-1) which is 255. If it is size_t, we don't have such a limit.

I do not think it's correct. With `array[size]`, the data type is `size_t` and the array size is `size_t`, effectively becoming `std::vector<size_t>`.
With `array[byte]`, the data type is `uint8_t`, and the array size is still `size_t`, becoming `std::vector<uint8_t>`. I think the later is more appropriate for this property.

You are right and I misunderstood it! I misread the "array[byte]", it should be read as an "array" of data whose type is "byte". Initially, I thought "byte" here refers to the data type of the length of the array. It is a big misunderstanding on my side 😂

I have to take back what I said in my last comment. Here it needs to be array[size]. The reason is this is an array of MeasurementIndices, if each index is of data type uint8_t, that means the index can not be bigger than 255, which means we have a hard limit on how big the index can be. 

You are still right about the array size, which can be bigger than 255, but by setting the index type as byte or uint8_t, we are actually putting a limit on how many measurement blocks can we have( which also tells about how big the measurement block index can be).

OK. So what is the "data struct" of each indice? If it's something like integer it's OK to use `size`. But if we know the length of the data, it's better to specify the data type. `size` here depends on the BMC architecutre, on ARM32 it's uint32_t, but in future BMC chips with 64bit arch, it becomes uint64_t.

Please consider using a more specific type here.

Since it is an "array of indices" it seems like size is appropriate?

My expectation is that these are similar to PCR indexes.  You ask for a measurement containing PCR0 + PCR8 = [ 0, 8 ].

Yes, it is an array of indices. The PCR example is correct.

> So what is the "data struct" of each indice? 
each index is just an index used to locate the measurement block. For example, it MeasurementIndices can be [1, 3, 100], which means it ask for measurement block 1, 3, 100 to be reported.
With that in mind, I think `size` is appropriate here.  I'll give Lei YU 24 hrs to give follow up feedback.

Got it. I'm OK here.

But for the record, we met issues with `size` type in PDI:
* The the different architectures (32-bit vs 64-bit) produce different types, and if such types are going to be serialized/de-serialized, it's likely to have issue.
* Internally we are going to implement the BMC config backup and restores functions. The above issue will cause the backup archive not to work on future 64-bit architectures. (As I know next generation of BMC chips will use 64-bit arch)
We should probably do something in sdbusplus where the generated bindings still use size_t but the dbus level it uses uint64 for the transport.
Possibly refer this as Certificate object path, so it is more clear
make sense, will change the description
Could throw other errors, e.g. internal failure, or some other errors?
Good point, will add it.

Currently certificates supports X.509 public certificate in PEM format. PEM wiki -
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Privacy-Enhanced_Mail . Is this certificate also comes under the same format?
Yes. If the original device certificate is not in PEM format, the d-bus daemon should convert it to PEM format and create a certificate dbus certificate object for it.
Please make sure to rebase this when submitting the next patch set also.

Sorry for the late update!

I've addressed all the comments, please see the updated patchset. Thanks!
Are we expecting anyone to parse this inside the BMC or is this only going to be used externally via Redfish?  Generally we don't like parsing/matching on arbitrary strings.
No parsing needed inside BMC, this TypeVersion will be used externally via Redfish.
in milliseconds since the epoch?
Yes, let me add it in the description.
Why does this matter?
It should not matter from d-bus point-of-view. The date format in string is specified by the Redfish spec. let me remove it from here to make the d-bus interface more generic.
You haven't introduced TrustedComponent yet.  Probably should move this to the next commit.
Make sense. let me move it to next commit.
Do we need to add the reverse to Inventory.Item?

Yes. I actually find a more proprietary name for this association. ComponentIntegrity object authenticates the integrity of the component (e.g., GPU, or other devices). I changed the association name to "authenticating/authenticated_by" and add the reverse in Inventory.Item.

The dbus code allows multiple returns, which automatically turns it into a tuple.  This is really equivalent to the code you have except that we can natively document each return value instead of having them embedded in the description.  Can you try that?
Yes, updated. Thanks!
I really don't like seeing new InternalFailures added.  What is a caller expected to do with this?  There isn't anything they can do to recover, so why tell them?

My understanding is this error type provide more info for debugging. 
For example, in the implementation of this dbus method, it will check whether parameters are valid, if not, report InvalidArgument error. 
If error happens inside the device, e.g., something goes wrong inside the RoT(root of trust) while preparing measurements, by reporting InternalFailure, we know it is an internal error within the device. So it is about providing accurate debug info, not for recovery. Does it make sense?
These aren't the association names you added to IdentityAuthentication.
Updated to match the associations added to IdentityAuthentication.
Please rebase and fix merge conflicts.
- After discovery of MCTP Endpoints, Create the D-bus object implementing the Attestation.ComponentIntegrity after the SPDM GET Version response???

Is it end device?

In the example below we have the ERoT(External RoT) which is protecting the end device

BMC---(SPDM)---ERoT_CPU---CPU

Authenticating would be pointing to ERoT_CPU or CPU and also what would be the authenticated_by pointing to?

This needs to be updated. In the newer version, there are two type of associations defined here:

```
+associations:
+    - name: reporting
+      description: >
+          Objects that implement ComponentIntegrity can implement the
+          "reporting" association to provide a link to the target trusted
+          component whose integrity this resource reports.
+      reverse_name: reported_by
+      required_endpoint_interfaces:
+          - xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item.TrustedComponent
+
+    - name: protecting
+      description: >
+          Objects that implement ComponentIntegrity can implement the
+          "protecting" association to provide a link to the target component
+          whose security this resource protects.
+      reverse_name: protected_by
+      required_endpoint_interfaces:
+          - xyz.openbmc_project.Inventory.Item
```

For reporting, it is associated with TrustedComponent, namely EROT in your example;
For protecting, it is associated with component, namely CPU in your example.

Will update it, thanks for pointing it out.

Sorry, I mixed the association names in the above reply, please ignore it.

To answer your question, "authenticating" is associated with the CPU in your example. ComponentIntegrity object authenticates the integrity of the component (e.g., GPU, CPU, or other devices).

"reporting" association, which is added in the following commit, is associated with the EROT, in your example, which means ComponentIntegrity object is reporting the measurement done by the EROT.
Is it assumed that this method will be synchronous call?

Actually, this method will be called from bmcweb using 
```
crow::connections::systemBus->async_method_call(
                    [asyncResp](const boost::system::error_code& e,
                                const RespStruct& resp) {}
```

Does it help?
why this is needed when we have the certificate?
It is actually redundant, the verifier can use the certificate. I kept it to make it compliant with the DMTF/Redfish schema definition for SPDMGetSignedMeasurements action.

Hi there, now the design doc for adding spdm support in openbmc has been merged (https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/docs/+/64994) I would like to have the d-bus interface be agreed on before I start submitting patches for bmcweb and spdm daemon. So feedbacks are appreciated here, thanks!
"is to be signed" ?
yes, let me correct it. thanks
Looks like `prettier` isn't happy.
solved.
